title: Board nomination statements aren’t rerendered on editing
body:
<!--
This is the repository and issue tracker for https://www.python.org
website.

If you're looking to file an issue with CPython itself, please go to
https://bugs.python.org

Issues related to Python's documentation (https://docs.python.org) can
also be filed in https://bugs.python.org, by selecting the
"Documentation" component.
-->

**Describe the bug**
I tried editing the board nomination statement and it seems to store the changes to the markdown but it doesn’t render the changes on the nomination detail page.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Create a board nomination
2. Edit nomination statement with change in Markdown code
3. See change not reflected in rendered version of statement

**Expected behavior**
Rerendering the Markdown on save.

**Screenshots**
Nomination 32

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: iOS 12 on iPad Pro
 - Browser: Safari
 - Version: latest

title: Download Page Not Appearing Correctly
body: The download page appears as raw text. A note at the top says I don't have JavaScript enabled but I do. Using the latest Google Chrome. The main page looks normal.

title: pubkeys.txt contains bogus keys
body:
I have moved this issue from the Cpython bug tracker : https://bugs.python.org/issue36191 to here 

Then, quoting Thomas Jollans (tjollans).

The file https://www.python.org/static/files/pubkeys.txt contains some bogus GPG keys with 32-bit key IDs identical to actual release manager key IDs. (see below) I imagine these slipped in by accident and may have been created by someone trying to make a point. (see also: https://evil32.com/)

This is obviously not a serious security concern, but it would be a better look if the file contained only the real keys, and if https://www.python.org/downloads/ listed fingerprints.

Pointed out by Peter Otten on python-list. https://mail.python.org/pipermail/python-list/2019-March/739788.html

These are the obvious fake keys included: 

```

title: PEP source link regression
body:
**Describe the bug**

See #1195. The links are now pointing back to .txt again.

Example: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-8016/#id24

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-8016/#id24
2. Click on the source link
3. GitHub responses with 404

**Expected behavior**
The link should point to the correct source.

title: Job board review is broken
body:
The job review pages no longer show the usual canned response drop-down and the accept/reject buttons are gone as well.

See e.g. https://www.python.org/jobs/2877/

The pages now only allow to leave a custom written comment.

Could you please restore the previous state, since in the current version, only the overview page has accept/reject buttons left, which makes review harder than ever before.

Thanks.

title: Session takeover vulnerability/bug Found on python.org
body:
Hi there, I noticed session takeover vulnerability on python.org. 
Details are as follows :

**Browser I Used**
1.  Mozilla Firefox v48
2.  Google Chromium v51

**Operating System Used**
Windows 8.1 also checked Edubuntu 14.04

**Login Required**
Yes

**Vulnerable Link**
[https://www.python.org](url)

**Description**
Sessions of users accounts not terminated after been password changed

**Steps to reproduce issue** 
        _(You have to use two browsers here. You can use Incognito mode)_
1.  Register an account  on  [https://www.python.org](url) with a valid information. 
2.  Logged into your account with first browser
3.  On second browser, Login on same account  and  Change/Reset  password.
4.  Now goto first browser and  refresh the link i.e. [https://www.python.org](url). You will notice that  sessions are still alive and not terminated.

**Possible Impact Scenario** 
Suppose Victim Logged into his account at internet cafe and forgot to Logout. 
Suppose You are attacker and you found victims account is open on same PC. Now attacker can download 'EditThisCookie 1.4.1' Chrome extension and export/copy cookie of victims acc  in text file. 
Now victim get to know that someone is using his acc and he just change password.
But attacker have victims account's cookies so he can just import that cookie with 'EditThisCookie 1.4.1'  and use victims account anytime because all sessions are not get terminating after password change. This may leads to miss-use of victims details and account . 

**Expected**
All live sessions must  terminate after password changed.

title: We can put any email id (already registered email also) in "Edit User Profile Page".
Save profile shows Error 404: File not Foud
body: Navigate to User account -> Edit your user profile; then fill out all fields and choose "Don't allow search engines to index my profile page", "Only logged-in users can see my e-mail address" and do not check "Make my profile public". The information will be saved, but you will be redirect to an Error 404 page.

title: search results style problem(eg:india in search bar)
body:
when i do a search in the site the result it shows has broken styles
![screenshot from 2016-04-07 11 26 21](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6927891/14341987/f4b011f2-fcb3-11e5-9ec6-74f3142184d6.png). am attached the screen shot with this issue.

title: Please drop leading zeros from PEP numbers
body: The title of e.g. PEP 8 is shown as PEP 0008: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/ While it's correct to have the leading zeros in the URLs, they should not appear in the title. The PEP is commonly known as "PEP 8", not "PEP 0008". (I see the latter pop up occasionally, probably because the website shows it that way, but it's really ugly and unnecessary.)

title: Display issues with event search results
body:
Currently when I search for events on python.org (from https://www.python.org/events/), the rendered page has a number of display issues (https://www.python.org/search/?q=london&submit=).

Below ~800px, the yellow element (CSS class .single-event-date) which should show some date information, is just displaying the nonsensical string "From at through at ,". Here's a screenshot from mobile safari:

![mobile_safari_pyorg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1864489/12797021/e88d3a52-cab9-11e5-86fc-563c89683b6e.jpg)

Above ~800px, the elements of the text mentioned above are stacked on top of each other (.single-event-date > .date-start and .single-event-date > .date-end). Here's a screenshot from Chrome on Mac OS X:

![pyorg](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1864489/12796759/5bfa94b4-cab8-11e5-971a-fe61cfac4b89.jpg)

title: Duplicate email signup possible
Missing possibility for users to delete their account or change PSF membership status
body:
Dear all,

it is a good idea to add a "delete" button in main menu to permit to all users to delete one's profile from python.org web site and/or PSF subscription without passing everytime times from psf@python.org email.

What do you think about?
Cheers

title: Old PEP links no longer work
body:
There are many links out in the wild (the wiki.python.org is full of such links) which use the old PEP link structure, e.g.

http://www.python.org/peps/pep-0255.html

These should get redirected to the new URL:

https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0255/

Probably best to do this using an nginx rewrite rule.

title: Plain text PEPs have duplicate "PEP nnn -" in their title
body:
See e.g.
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0255/ and
https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0100/

title: NoReverseMatch for usernames containing +
body:
Saw this at Sentry: https://app.getsentry.com/python-software-foundation/production/group/62615414/

The question is should we allow + in username and slug (slug is acvtually the username field here) fields (see https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/blob/master/users/urls.py#L17), or should be raise a ValidationError in https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/blob/master/users/forms.py#L9?

title: load_dev_fixtures raises IntegrityError
body:
With a fresh database:

``` shell
$ export DATABASE_URL=postgres:///pydotorgtest
$ ./manage.py migrate
$ ./manage.py load_dev_fixtures
...
...
django.db.utils.IntegrityError: Problem installing fixture '/tmp/dev-fixtures.json.gz': Could not load jobs.Job(pk=1): null value in column "job_title" violates not-null constraint
```

See pk=1 job entry on admin interface: https://www.python.org/admin/jobs/job/1/

I think the problem is old job entries. Some of the entries have empty "job_title" field. Dumping entries from 2015 (or deleting incomplete and useless entries) would solve the problem.

title: Site doesn't allow users to edit their name entries
body:
If you go to https://www.python.org/users/edit/ after login, you can only edit some preferences, but it's impossible to edit the first and last name entries of the record.

Looking through some records, it seems that only very few of the 16k+ user entries we have on the site has the first and last name set on the user record, so there may well also be a bug in the signup procedure.

title: Submissions emails should only be sent for new submissions
body:
While #656 fixed the number of emails we're getting, the problem of getting approval emails for every single change of a record still isn't fixed.

We should really only be getting emails with the subject "Job Submitted for Approval" for new submissions.

It may make sense to also get emails for changes to existing records, but those should then be using a different subject, e.g. "Job Edited", but I'm not sure whether that's really needed.

title: Edit page in review panel causes 502 error
body:
See e.g. https://www.python.org/jobs/159/edit/
Click on "submit".

For some reason, the selected job technology "Evangelism" is _deleted_ from the database as a result of clicking submit.

title: job submission form is broken, gives you a File Not Found AFTER you complete the required data
body:
Job submission form is broken, gives you a File Not Found AFTER you complete the required data

https://www.python.org/newjobs/create/

In addition to the not working anymore submission of job by email now we have this new cool form which seems to give you a File Not Found error page once you manage to complete all the required data. Same happens for Save as Draft or Submit for Approval.

Also is not clear if the email address from the form would become public (as we may not want to give our email address, preferring to ask people to use the provided url to submit CVs).

title: Not all displays honor 90 day threshold
PEPs RSS is broken
body: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/peps.rss linked to from the main page gives something broken. It looks like the RSS is escaped, embedded inside the site's HTML template.

title: Jobs: Stay Up To Date links never updated
body: Originally reported here https://github.com/python-jobs-board/pythondotorg/issues/41

title: Jobs: Don't show "Looking for:" if empty
Job Title missing from Job list descriptions
Job Company selection
body:
If user chooses specific company, remove 'Company Name' and 'Company Description' options via JS. 

Originally reported https://github.com/python-jobs-board/pythondotorg/issues/35

title: Jobs: Confusing login links in sidebar/creation
body: Originally reported https://github.com/python-jobs-board/pythondotorg/issues/40

title: Job Description and Requirements not required fields
body: Reported by @VanL via email.

title: 1.7 Migrations Broken!!!! Might hold off on contributions for now.
body:
So moving Python.org to Django 1.7 went smoothy, UNTIL I went blow out the South migrations.  Sadly django-markupfield doesn't support 1.7 migrations and seems there is no plan/way to do so easily.

I'm in the process of formulating a plan to remove django-markupfield from the codebase, but it's gonna take me a couple of days before it is finished.  Wanted to add this Issue to serve as a warning to others who might be contributing to the project.

title: CSS issue: background turns black for long pages
body:
See the PSF resolutions page for an example:

https://www.python.org/psf/records/board/resolutions/

About 2/3 of the page are rendered with black background. Tested on Firefox and SeaMonkey.

title: Errors in C++ sig page
body:
From webmaster mail:

---

I'm not sure where to report bugs about the Python.org web site. If
this is the wrong place please tell we the right one so I can do better
next time :-)

The page https://www.python.org/community/sigs/current/cplusplus-sig/
contains lots of error messages from docutils and is hardly readable. It
looks like someone accidentally used HTML as input for docutils.

As it doesn't seem to have seen any updates in the last 12 years it
probably should be removed anyway.

title: Calendar event pages show description as plain text
body:
This was already fixed some time ago in #156, but has now resurfaced for all events entered more recently.

See e.g.

https://www.python.org/events/python-user-group/174/
https://www.python.org/events/python-user-group/167/
https://www.python.org/events/python-user-group/169/

The problem does not exist for older entries.

title: Signup allows periods in usernames, UserDetail url regex does not
Events are shown one day longer than scheduled
body:
See e.g. https://www.python.org/events/python-events/?page=2

PyCon UK is from Sept 19-22, but the listing shows Sept 19-23.

I guess this has to do with timezones again. Note that most events in the events calendar are full day events.

title: Some events are missing in the calendar events listings
body:
If you compare the listing on the frontpage with the calendar view on http://pycon.org/ there are several user group events not shown in the box.

It is not completely clear whether this is related to repeating events or not, since e.g. the "Guadalajara, Mexico PUG" event is shown and is repeating, while e.g. the "London Python Code Dojo" event on April 2 is not shown. The problem seems to have to do with repeating events, though, since the "Python Meeting Düsseldorf" on April 29 is the first non-repeating event after PyCon US 2014.

title: Django admin gives an internal server error for the jobs table
body:
It looks like the migrations we merged yesterday caused a problem:

https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/pull/319

Could one of the admins please paste the traceback here, so that we can have a look. It would also be good to get a table dump of the jobs, job type and job category tables in order to debug the problem on the test server we have setup for the jobs app development.

Thanks.

title: Editing the job board page causes an Internal Server Error
body:
I'm trying to remove an entry from the job board page (https://www.python.org/admin/pages/page/57/), but keep getting an Internal Server Error message when trying to save the edit, with no further details. Here's the HTML - perhaps the formatting hints at the origin of the error: ``` Internal Server Error

Internal Server Error

```

title: "Jobs" link at top of home page is incorrect
body:
This is kind of urgent. We have two jobs pages:

http://www.python.org/community/jobs/

and

http://www.python.org/newjobs/

The latter URL is linked from the top of (apparently) every page on the site. It must not be live yet! All links should be to the community/jobs page for the time being.

title: Page editing doesn't work anymore
body:
I tried to edit the PSF grants page (http://www.python.org/psf/grants/) using the "Edit" button. This redirected me to the enty form (http://www.python.org/admin/pages/page/420/). I then entered the change (fixing the last Q/A).

Hitting "Save" always returns an empty page and the URL stays at http://www.python.org/admin/pages/page/420/ instead of redirecting to http://www.python.org/admin/pages/page/ as it did before.

title: Caching and CSRF protection don't like each other
body:
The system heavily caches the jobs board interface under /newjobs/. This apparently creates problems with the CSRF protection mechanisms used by Django in web forms:

 <input type='hidden' name='csrfmiddlewaretoken' value='CyVJix8GA2SlVUAeD5AKyqtPJLConvzP' />

As example, I tried to file a comment on this test job posting:

http://www.python.org/newjobs/98/review/

and failed. Django always returns a 403 "CSRF verification failed. Request aborted.".

I tried reloading the review page and reentering the data, but the problem persists. This renders the jobs app system unusable.

Could someone please turn off this heavy caching for pages that use Django forms ?

For the jobs board the URLs live under /jobs/ and /newjobs/.

Also see #284.

Thanks.

title: Job navigation should not include non-approved job postings
body:
Currently (12/3/14 10:12 GMT) Two jobs showing on top counter of Job section. if you click on job page there is navigation at bottom for next and previous job which explore more job and surely more then two jobs.

There are some jobs not published correctly or they are not meant to show online ??

title: Site caching doesn't honor forced reloads / admin pages don't show changes
body:
When working on the site, I often find that the browser is hitting cached pages with old content, sometimes even on pages that should always be dynamically regenerated when loading them like e.g. the admin page for the site tree.

In order to check edits to the site and make admin pages like the site tree usable, it is important that:
- the admin page do not get cached and that
- all other cached pages do get recreated when using forced reload from the browser.

title: Job reviews should be possible for group "Job Board Admin"
body:
Or more specifically: users with permission to change the Jobs table records.

At the moment the views for dealing with the reviews use the SuperuserRequiredMixin which prevents the job board team members in the user group to review jobs.

Locations:
https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/blob/master/jobs/views.py#L114
https://github.com/python/pythondotorg/blob/master/jobs/views.py#L168

title: Login and signup pages should only be available via HTTPS
body:
At the moment, the site asks for logins and signups on HTTP pages, which is completely unsecure.

Given how easy it is to grab credentials at conferences using open WLANs, this is a major security risk for the site.

Also see #76, #122 and #213.

title: API key admin interface: show user names
body: The interface at http://python.org/admin/tastypie/apikey/ simply lists "ApiKey object" for each entry. That makes it impossible to find the API key for a given user quickly.

title: Email sent by the site has an invalid email address
body: Through circuitous means, I got an email bounce this morning that purported to be from webmaster@localhost.python.org. Patrick Ben Koetter, one of the python.org postmasters said that the "localhost." part needs to go. This seems fairly high-priority, as it will likely affect all email generated by the site.

title: Admin page should only be accessible via https
body:
#74 discusses that the admin page shouldn't be publicly available. Even after that is fixed, nginx should be configured so that all admin pages are only available over https. This will prevent MITM (e.g. over public wifi) from occurring. 

It would be nice if everything were https, but the admin page definitely should be.

title: Security issue: http://python.org/ needs to redirect to https://www.python.org/
body:
Since python.org can now be used to log into to the site, the code base needs to make sure that no python.org (without the www.) cookies are set and that all requests to the bare domain get redirected to www.python.org.

Not doing so could otherwise lead to cookie/session stealing attacks from other python.org sub-sites.

I just checked: logging in via python.org (without www.) sets cookies on the domain python.org, not www.python.org. Doing the login on www.python.org sets the cookies on the domain www.python.org.

Of course, the same redirection should happen for http://python.org/ and https://python.org/.

title: News and Events on Homepage are still sample text
body: There is a Trello card for this as well, under "To Do: Content". Partially a content issue, partially a code issue.

title: Sample code box is too tall
body:
On the compound data types example, the code pushes the bottom of the box down:

![screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/I117LK2.png)

This is in Chrome on a retina Mac.
